msContents.summary: This beautifully illuminated multi-text manuscript is written on black paper in golden ink. It was completed in 1791 CE in Kathmandu in a vihāra called Hemākra and commisioned by a Vajrācārya named ‏Abhayananda ‏Abhayananda Abhayanandra (written Abhayanandra in the colophon). The manuscript contains the follwing Buddhist texts: the Pañcarakṣā (only the dhāraṇī part), the Abhayakarīdhāraṇī (recorded as Abhayakalidhāraṇī in the colophon), the Tārābhaṭṭārikāṣṭottaraśataka and the Mahākālamantradhāna (strangely added after the colophon). The Pañcarakṣā "Five Protections" consists of the Mahāpratisarā, Mahāmāyūrī, Mahāsāhasrapramardanī, Mahāmantrānusāriṇī, and Mahāśītavatī. The earliest evidence for texts grouped together as the "Five Great Dhāraṇīs" comes from Tibetan catalogues around 800 CE, but this compendium is somewhat different from the surviving Sanskrit collection, which is preserved in manuscripts dating back to the eleventh century. These scriptures include spells, enumerations of benefits and ritual instructions for use. With the course of time all of them became deified and five related goddesses emerged. It is, however, important to note that the texts themselves do not have any references to these goddesses. The other texts are little known and yet unpublished.

msItem.incipit: [3v1] evan mayā śrutaṃm eka[3v2]smiṃ samaye bhagavāṃ vajrameruśikha¦[miniature]re kūṭāṃgāre vihalati sma ||
msItem.finalRubric: [16v2] || @ || ā[miniature]ryyamahāmāyūrīvidyārajñī avi[103v4]naṣṭā yakṣamukhāt pratilabdhā samā-1-ptā bhaga¦%vatī || @ ||
msItem.explicit: [20v3] || jāniha bhūtāni samāgatāni, sthitāni, bhūmāṃv athavāntalekṣe, kurvantu tavaikṣā sa[20v4]tataṃ prajāsu divā ca rātrau ca carantu dharma || iti tatra buddhānāṃ buddhaānubhāvena, devatānāṃ devatā[20r5]nādevanubhāvena mahātītrupraśānti || @ ||
msItem.finalRubric: [21r1] āryyamahāpratisarā, āryyamahāsāhasrapramardani, āyyasāyuli [21r2] āryyamahāśitavati āryyamahāmantrānusāruni ḥ ete pañcamahārakṣāsūtrāni bhāṣitā[21r3] ni, dhāranī palisamāpta || @ || @ ||

Abhayakarīnāmadhāraṇī
msItem.incipit: [21r3] oṃ namo bhagava[21r4]tya āryyavalokṛteśvarāya bodhisatvāya mahāsatvāya mahākāruṇikāya || tadyathā ||
msItem.colophon: [22r4] sarvvabuddhaṃ namasyāmi dha[22r5]rmacajitabhāṣita, saghacasirasaparnnaratnatraya namastute || @ || vasudhārā sadā natvāddha[22v1]riḍānavatāraṇī, rakṣisiddhivara[miniature]padāḥ || @ || @

Tārābhaṭṭārikāstotra
Tārābhaṭṭārikāśataka
msItem.incipit: [22v2] śrīmatpo[miniature]talake ramye, nānādhātuvirājite ḥ || nānādrumalatākirṇṇe nānāpakṣi¦[miniature]ṇi kūjite ||
msItem.explicit: [28r3] kalyāṇami-1-sevī ¦[29r4] bodhicittavibhūṣinaḥ sadā virahito buddhai, yatra yatropapadyate itti || @ || @ ||
msItem.finalRubric: [28r5] āryyatārābhaṭṭāri nāma dhāraṇī ḥ nāmāṣṭottarasatakaṃ buddhabhāṣitasamāpta || @ || [28v1] @ ||
msItem.colophon: [28v1] ye dharmmā hetuprabhāvā hevat_ tu teṣāṃ, tathāgata, havadat eṣāṃ ca jo nirodha evaṃvādi ma[28v2]hāśravaṇaḥ || @ || śreyo stu || samvat_ 911 sti avamāsya śuklapakṣe pūrṇṇamāsyāṃ tithau || śra[28v3]vaṇanakṣatre, saubhāgyayājñe, jathā karṇṇamuhūtra āditavāre śrasiṃharāsigate, sapitre, makra[28v4]rāsigate, candramasi ḥ || dānapati, śuvarṇṇapanarima2 hānaga 2lya, tambarācchitora, etārivi nāma [28v5] gṛhe vasthita, turādha, bhāvanandra, kasya utrāpaṣṭhahnāsa nāma sirddhabhuvana,nānāvānijanyopā [29r1]rasāthabāhu avatālakahusya conāvarat_, manasa atidharmacirtta utpatihuyāja, thamana[29r2] nistapyayāta, nīrapratre suvarṇṇcūrṇena likhāpitāḥ || @ || riṣitaṃ, hemākramahā[29r3]vihāle vasthita śrīvajrācāryya, abhayanandrasya liṣāpitaṃ iti || ete dharmmana jojamā[29r4] na āyu ālogya, janadhanasukhasaṃppatiphara, bhavantu || iha loke, śrīpañcarakṣā nāma dhāra[29r5]ni mahāmāyā sudhisti bhavantu || @ || evan samārādhyaṃ gatantu, śrīsaranasavā || @ [29v1] || thva, pañcarākṣāpuṣṭakadhārani davakaṃ tayā bhinakaṃ nistapakaṃ tayamāla || @ || śubhama¦[29v2]ṅgaraṃ bhavantu sarvvadākāraṃ || śubha || @ ||

msItem.title: Mahākālamantradhāna
msItem.incipit: [30r1] eva mayā śrutaṃm ekasminṃn sama¦[30r2]ye bhagavāṃ devinā bhageṣu yathāna[miniature]rtha, tathā vijahāred iti |
msItem.explicit: [30v5] || @ || oṃ mahākāla 2 huṃ huṃ phaṭ_ 2 svāhā || [30v6] oṃ ūṃ kī huṃ huṃ phaṭ_ svāhā || @ ||

supportDesc.foliation: Nepālākṣarā letter numerals, mid-left margin, verso.
supportDesc.condition: Incomplete, in good condition, although the writing is sometimes smudged and difficult to read.

layoutDesc.layout:
4.5 18
The written area is smaller than the area demarcated by the frame.
5 lines per page, approximately 33 akṣaras per line.
5
4
The frame has been singled out by glazing the paper. 5.5 20.7 Triple marginal frame lines in golden ink, ruling. Double and triple marginal frame lines in gold ink. Ruling. Unlike in many illuminated Buddhist manuscripts, in which the miniatures are added after the text is written, in this manuscripts they have been prepared before the texts: this is clear from the fact that on folio 9, the text is written also in the space left blank for the miniature, and on folio 30r, the writing lies on the miniature of the god Mahākāla.

decoNote.desc:
The beginnings of the various texts are decorated with polychrome miniatures of approximately 5 cm in width, put in the centre of the page and protected by Japanese paper:
On f. 3v, representation of the goddess Mahāpratisarā.
On f. 10r, representation of the goddess Mahāpāhasrapramardanī.
On f. 12r, representation of the goddess Mahāmayūrī.
On f. 16v, representation the goddess Mahāśitavatī.
On f. 18v, representation the goddess Mahāmantrānusāriṇī.
On f. 21v, representation the goddess Abhayakarī.
On f. 22v, representation the goddess Tārā.
On f. 30r, representation the god Mahākāla.

list.item: On the recto of the flyleaf at the end of the manuscript, a note in Nepālākṣarā, in silver ink, reads: "[l1] $ oṃ nama samantrabuddhānāṃ mahāguṇadravyānāṃ $ [l2] oṃ nama bhāgava".

history.provenance:
Bought by Wright, Daniel Dr. D. Wright
in 1873-6.
